Award.AwardTitle: ATD: Collaborative Research: Efficient sampling for real-time detection and isolation of threats in networks
Award.AbstractNarration:
While modern technologies generate multiple, interconnected sources of data, which can be observed in nearly real time, physical constraints and budget limitations require efficient sampling of these data streams. Incorporating such constraints in the design of threat detection systems has the potential to lead to significant savings in resources. The goal of this project is to develop fundamental statistical theory and methods for the efficient, real-time sampling of networks, and the subsequent detection, identification and prevention of threats of different nature, such as terrorist activities and credit fraud. The developed methodologies will be tested on real-world data, where the underlying community structure in times of crisis will be discovered using cell-phone call records. The theoretical knowledge that will be gained in this project will be incorporated into the material of graduate-level courses that cover adaptive experimental design and sequential detection. Two graduate students will contribute significantly in this research. The project will make every effort to include qualified students of underrepresented groups in these research activities.

This research will address two fundamental research questions: 1) how to detect and identify, in real time, anomalous clusters in network data subject to sampling constraints, and 2) how to efficiently allocate limited resources in order to delay or prevent the realization of threats from the identified anomalous clusters. The mathematical formulation of these questions leads to novel problems in network-based, adaptive experimental design and sequential detection, whose solutions require the creative combination of tools from various fields, such as statistical inference, sequential analysis, and information theory. The theory and methods developed in this work will guide the development of threat detection algorithms and will be tested in concrete applications, such as social networks in times of crisis that will be discovered based on cell-phone call data. Overall, this is a multidisciplinary proposal, spanning social sciences, statistics, and engineering, whose goal is to obtain an arsenal of efficient network sampling schemes and novel threat detection algorithms, grounded on a strong theoretical background.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Broader impact:

The research program has significant and multifaceted technological and societal impacts. The theoretical advances obtained have strong practical impact on the design of threat detection systems and platforms. Specifically, this research program has developed threat detection algorithms that are theoretically-principled and recognize important physical constraints associated data acquisition and processing in large-scale surveillance systems. Many threat detection tasks, such credit fraud detection and detection of terrorist activity require extracting latent features from a partially observable, dynamic, and directed network. We have developed a network model that can capture all the delicate relationships among the latent features and the physical constraints in sensing and data acquisition. Furthermore, the blend of theoretical and simulation-based investigations in this project has provided a unique and invaluable opportunity for training of future statisticians and engineers.

 

Intellectual merit:

Specifically, this research  program contributed to the theoretical foundations of detection abrupt changes in complex networks. In particular, it has delineated the interplay among the performance guarantees on the decisions about the accuracy of the decisions, cost of sensing, communication delay tolerance, and the uncertainty level about model dynamics. Characterizing such an interplay has led to designing novel active sensing procedures in which an optimal balance among can be struck among different aspects based on the operational needs. Furthermore, this research has led to novel theoretical and conceptual developments in sequential experimental design and decision making under model uncertainties, founded at the interface of sequential statistics, stochastic optimization, and statistical signal processing. The theoretical results have also provided the guidelines for designing low-complexity and responsive spectrum sensing procedures.

 

Specific outcomes:

The research outcomes of this project lead to understanding, at a fundamental level, the principles of designing algorithms for detecting abrupt changes in networks. The key parameters that were incorporated in the model as the performance metrics include:

  • the cost of data-acquisition (sensing);
  • communication latency;
  • sensing and communication model uncertainties; and
  • dynamic spatiotemporal variations of the covariates underpinning and modeling threats

 

Under such settings, various threat detection in complex networks have been investigated. The project developed a unified framework for assessing the algorithm such that the effects of all these factors are accounted for. The core element of this framework was developing the analytical tools that can theoretically establish the fundamental tradeoffs among these factors. By determining such interplay one can evaluate the relative merits of different threat detection strategies, and also provide the guidelines for the optimal strategies based on the need of the application, e.g., based on the latency tolerance and model uncertainty one can determine what is the performance of the network is. Additionally, driven by the insights gained from the uncovered fundamental limits we developed threat detection algorithms that are amenable to real-time and fast implementation, exhibit sound detection guarantees, and are fully adaptive and responsive to the temporal evolution of the state of the network.
